image.altText: Nicola Spurrier at press conference

items.synopsis: Two new cases of tuberculosis have been identified in SA, with health authorities working on contact tracing

title.children: Health authorities concerned about possibility of third TB cluster after two new cases detected in SA

image.altText: A house under construction with a green skip bin in the foreground

items.synopsis: Yet another South Australian builder has gone into voluntary administration, citing fixed price contracts as a factor behind debts of more than $1 million.

title.children: Another South Australian builder goes bust, Residence Building Group appoints voluntary administrator

image.altText: Composite image of Clare O'Neil and Peter Dutton

items.synopsis: Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil has accused Peter Dutton of "starving" the immigration system of resources and allowing criminal syndicates to exploit weaknesses.

title.children: 'An amazing fraud': Home affairs minister attacks Dutton's immigration credentials

image.altText: A close-up of the backs of the heads of two Aboriginal children.

items.synopsis: South Australia's Aboriginal Children's Commissioner is urging the state government to reduce the number of First Nations children entering out-of-home care, to avoid a repeat of the Stolen Generation.

title.children: SA Aboriginal children entering care predicted to reach Stolen Generation levels without change, report finds

image.altText: A greyhound in a kennel.

items.synopsis: As a former greyhound adoption worker speaks out about what she witnessed during her time in the industry, an MP releases what she described as "graphic and concerning and disturbing" photos of emaciated dogs and squalid kennels. Warning: This story contains content that may distress some readers.

title.children: Greyhound mistreatment concerns trigger release of 'concerning and disturbing' photos in parliament

image.altText: A sign saying Minda

items.synopsis: One of SA's largest disability service providers is fined more than $40,000 after a worker was sexually and physically assaulted by a youth in their care.

title.children: SA disability service provider fined after support worker assaulted

image.altText: A an old colour photo of a boys soccer team with a male coach. The boys' faces are blurred.

items.synopsis: The Beaumaris Primary School child sexual abuse inquiry has been expanded to include six more Victorian government schools and is hearing allegations regarding primary school teachers Grahame Harold Steele and David Ernest Keith MacGregor.

title.children: Beaumaris Primary child sexual abuse inquiry expanded as two more alleged perpetrators named

image.altText: A bronze bust stands next to a TV screen displaying a title card for the 2023 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.

items.synopsis: The announcement came after Sweden's Royal Academy of Sciences appeared to inadvertently release the names of the three scientists earlier in the day, when a Swedish newspaper published a copy of an email its said was from the academy and contained the names of the recipients.

title.children: Nobel Prize in Chemistry awarded to scientists who discovered quantum dots

items.synopsis: Heavy rain in Victoria brings some relief to firefighters, but residents in some communities in the state's east are now facing emergency flood warnings as river levels rise.

title.children: Victorian towns told to evacuate due to major flooding of Gippsland river

image.altText: A young woman pointing at a rainbow

items.synopsis: Two young women are able to leave hospital after they received stab wounds at the Australian National University in Canberra last month.

title.children: University students leave hospital as top cop defends dismissal of triple-0 call made by mental health nurse

image.altText: A low shot looking up at a sign on the side of Perth Children's Hospital.

items.synopsis: Charges against a teenage boy accused of raping a 13-year-old girl at Perth Children's Hospital were discontinued because of serious concerns about the safety and wellbeing of the alleged victim, it is revealed.

title.children: Charges over 13-year-old's alleged rape inside Perth Children's Hospital discontinued due to welfare concerns

image.altText: A woman looks directly at camera.

items.synopsis: Thousands of Australians opted to do their grocery shopping online during the pandemic, but plenty are yet to return to shopping in store as they try to get the most bang for their buck amid the high cost of living.

title.children: Sarah does 90 per cent of her grocery shopping online — but she's not checking out at the big supermarkets

image.altText: A smiling student with short dark curly hair wearing glasses and a colourful t-shirt holds a bottlebrush.

items.synopsis: As garden guides and knowledge holders, these high-schoolers in Port Pirie connect with country and culture like never before.

title.children: First Nations high-schoolers blossom in unique native garden program

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: Australians will be voting in the referendum on October 14. Look back at our live coverage of the campaign on Wednesday, October 4.

title.children: More than 900,000 early votes cast in Voice referendum in three days as AEC reaffirms impartiality — as it happened

image.altText: Older Indigenous man wearing a white shirt.

items.synopsis: While the prime minister has deflected questions about a national treaty, some Indigenous sovereign No campaigners want Australia to talk about it.

title.children: The No campaigners pushing for a treaty instead of the Voice

image.altText: Margo Ngawa Neale, who has silver and brown hair, clear framed spectacles and red lipstick, poses for a photo by a body of water

items.synopsis: Do you know what Country is or what it means to care for it? Ever heard of Songlines? Margo Ngawa Neale, senior Indigenous art and history curator at the National Museum of Australia, is here to help.

title.children: 'It is not a surface thing': Why we spell Country with a capital C

image.altText: A roll cloud over the ocean

items.synopsis: Thunderstorms and heavy rain are forecast for parts of Victoria and New South Wales, dousing fires but bringing the threat of flash flooding, as a low pressure system intensifies over the eastern states.

title.children: Dangerous wind, heavy rain, flooding forecast to hit eastern states as intense storm system deepens

image.altText: Four men standing outside talking.

items.synopsis: A man has been hospitalised and at least three homes have been lost as New South Wales south coast residents wait to see the damage left by a fire burning since Tuesday.

title.children: Prime minister urges Bega community to dig deep as homes are lost on NSW south coast

image.altText: A blonde, bespectacled woman casts her gaze downward as she leaves a court building, flanked by a lawyer in a suit.

items.synopsis: Nicole Louise Bourne has been fined $40,000 after pleading guilty to dozens of offences. The court heard that her Toowoomba store had attracted hundreds of complaints as well as the attention of the RSPCA.

title.children: Pet store owner escapes conviction despite 'appalling' treatment of more than 500 animals

image.altText: Pat Conroy Henry Puna

items.synopsis: The Pacific's top diplomat says Australia's credibility in the region will be bolstered if the nation votes in favour of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament on October 14.

title.children: Yes referendum outcome could bolster Australia's standing, Pacfic diplomat says

image.altText: group of indigenous men standing

items.synopsis: Since 2000, the percentage of Indigenous Australians in prison has risen at eight times the rate of that of non-Indigenous Australians. There are hopes a Voice to Parliament will help reverse that trend.

title.children: Australia has one of the highest Indigenous incarceration rates in the world. Could a Voice to Parliament change that?

image.altText: An Aboriginal man holds his hands under a tap

items.synopsis: The NT Supreme Court has ruled the territory government is responsible for supplying safe drinking water to its tenants, in a ruling advocates say could impact Indigenous communities across the country.

title.children: This community took the NT government to court over its water. The decision could help hundreds of others

image.altText: An unstaffed construction site beneath a clear sky.

items.synopsis: Chatham Homes has entered voluntary administration and industry figures say customers may have to pay more to get their houses completed.

title.children: Home builder's collapse leaves scores of projects unfinished in Victoria

image.altText: An aerial view of a huge fire in the outback.

items.synopsis: The massive blaze has been burning for weeks and has now caused the closure of the Barkly Highway as it continues to surge through cattle country.

title.children: NT fire that has burnt through 2 million hectares rages towards Queensland border

image.altText: A singer performing in a recording studio by some microphones.

items.synopsis: Australian operatic mezzo-soprano Jacqueline Dark has died on October 3, 2023 aged 55. Dark has performed across opera, music theatre, cabaret and on the concert stage.

title.children: Australian mezzo-soprano Jacqueline Dark has died aged 55

image.altText: A Western Bulldogs AFL player pumps his right fist during a 2023 match.

items.synopsis: Aaron Naughton is set to finish his career as a one-club player in the AFL after committing to the Bulldogs through until the end of the 2032 season.

title.children: Star Bulldogs forward signs staggering eight-year contract extension

image.altText: Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk delivers here CEDA State of the State address.

items.synopsis: Energy rebates and a $250 million fund to speed up Queensland's internet are announced in Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk's State of the State address.

title.children: Queensland premier reveals energy rebates, faster internet and the quantum 'frontier' in State of the State address

image.altText: a loose lightbulb on a black background

items.synopsis: To take just a few examples, Nobel Prize-winning physics has given us portable computers, efficient LED lighting, climate modelling and radiation treatment of cancer, writes Karen Livesey.

title.children: What has the Nobel Prize in Physics ever done for me? It solved the mystery of blue LEDs, for starters

image.altText: A bird's eye view of dozens of homes in a suburb, with a frame of one house being constructed.

items.synopsis: Australia's housing market is firmly in recovery mode as prices are on track to reach a new record high. Here's what's happening in your capital city.

title.children: Australian house prices are set to lift further as interest rates stabilise. Here's what's happening in your capital city

image.altText: A mother holds her 1 year old daughter at a birthday party outside.

items.synopsis: Just over six months since MasterChef judge and celebrity chef Jock Zonfrillo's sudden death, his wife Lauren shares that their family has celebrated their daughter Isla's birthday — the first without him.

title.children: 'To miss these days seems unfair and unbearable': Jock Zonfrillo's wife pens emotional post

image.altText: Flowers next to a tree with a police car in the background

items.synopsis: A road toll rise in parts of Australia has experts worried that we are going backwards on road safety.

title.children: There's a big misconception about mobile phones and driving, and it's putting us at risk

image.altText: A satellite in space

items.synopsis: The US Federal Communications Commission issues the first-ever fine for the improper disposal of space junk to television provider Dish Network

title.children: US regulator issues first fine for space junk

image.altText: Kevin McCarthy in profile

items.synopsis: For the first time in American history, members of congress have voted to dump the speaker in the House of Representatives, with Republicans turning on each other to oust Kevin McCarthy.

title.children: Insults, drama and Republicans on the brink: Why America's conservatives just tore down their leader

image.altText: A woman holds two historic photos with photo albums in the background on the table

items.synopsis: When walking through a state forest Ballarat resident Leanne found a collection of photo albums. She's trying build a picture of why family heirlooms were left in the bush.

title.children: Century-old photographs rescued by dog walker from forest rubbish dump
